Award.AwardTitle: RoL:FELS: Symposium: Mitonuclear compatibility as a rule for complex life; January 5, 2019; Tampa, FL
Award.AbstractNarration:
Evolutionary biology has led to breakthroughs in agriculture and medicine and provides a framework for understanding the Earth's biodiversity. The foundations of modern evolutionary biology were established before the discovery that there are important genes outside of the nucleus of the cell in mitochondria. This workshop is included under Rules of Life as it explores the significance of having genes carried in two distinct sets; this idea reframes key theories in evolutionary biology. New ideas on the role of mitochondrial genes in the evolution of organisms need to be discussed and further developed. To address these developing interests in the community, a symposium on has been organized for the 2019 meeting of the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB). The symposium is titled "Beyond the powerhouse: integrating mitonuclear evolution, physiology, and theory in comparative biology" and will bring together scientists who are working in diverse organismal systems to address emerging topics in mitonuclear ecology. The speakers will make formal presentation of the work being conducted in laboratories in the United States and around the world. The ideas that emerge from this meeting may advance medicine and agriculture. This symposium will include a diverse range of researchers that span career stages from graduate student to full professor, and all speakers will disseminate these findings in a special issue of Integrative and Comparative Biology.

Eukaryotes are the outcome of an ancient symbiosis and as such, eukaryotic cells possess both a nuclear and mitochondrial (mt) genome. Interactions between the mitochondrial and nuclear genomes, mitonuclear interactions, are an inherent feature of eukaryotic biology. Not surprisingly, mitonuclear interactions have been suggested to underlie the evolution of organismal complexity, environmental adaptation, the evolution of life history traits, and the process of speciation. Collectively, rethinking such classic eco-evolutionary processes in the light of mitonuclear interactions has recently been dubbed "mitonuclear ecology". To address these developing interests in the community, a symposium on mitonuclear ecology has been organized for the 2019 meeting of the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB). The speakers include experts in molecular evolution, the theory of mitonuclear coadaptation and conflict, and mitochondrial physiology. By presenting this combination of expertise, the goal is to inform the community of the importance of mitonuclear interactions, encourage others to consider these types of interactions in their own work, and develop new fields (e.g., mitonuclear ecophysiology).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mitonuclear ecology is emerging as an important new subdisciplines as scientists seek to understand the rules of life and to better integrate the biological sciences. Considering fundamental characteristics of biology in light this core property of eukaryotes has the potential to contribute to diverse fields and address key challenges in evolutionary biology. This NSF-sponsored symposium was ideally timed to present the field of Mitonuclear Ecology to the diverse group of evolutionary and organismal biologists that attend SICB.

      The interactions of mitochondrial and nuclear genes have been suggested to underlie the evolution of organismal complexity, the origins of sex, environmental adaptation, mechanisms of sexual selection, the evolution of life history traits, and the process of speciation. To address these developing interests in the community, we organized a symposium on mitonuclear ecology at the 2020 meeting of the Society of Integrative and Comparative Biology (SICB). The symposium was titled ?Beyond the powerhouse: integrating mitonuclear evolution, physiology, and theory in comparative biology? and brought together 11 scientists working in diverse organismal systems as core speakers along with 8 junior researchers in an affiliated session. The speakers included experts in molecular evolution, the theory of mitonuclear coadaptation and conflict, and mitochondrial physiology.

    The speakers in the symposium represented experts a range of career stages with both male and female speakers represented:

Damian Dowling, Senior Research Fellow, Monash University, Australia
Ana Jimenez, Assistant Professor, Colgate University
Ryan Greenway, NSF Graduate Research Fellow, Kansas State University
Inna Sokolova, Professor and Chair, University of Rostock, Germany
Eric Watson, Postdoctoral Scholar, University of Southern California
Geoffrey Hill, Professor, Auburn University
Kristi Montooth, Associate Professor, University of Nebraska
Wendy Hood, Assistant Professor, Auburn University
Suzanne Estes, Associate Professor, Portland State University
Patricia Schulte, Professor University of British Columbia, Canada

      By presenting this combination of expertise, we informed a key community of biological researchers about the importance of mitonuclear interactions.  We encouraged others to consider these types of interactions in their own work, rethink familiar themes, and develop new and interesting fields.

Broader Impacts

   Over 6 hours, the symposium was attended by approximately 650 scientists.  We conducted scan samples and distributed questionnaires and estimate that 400 of the attendees were undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral students.  We held an informal social the evening of the symposium with light hors d?oeuvres served.  Besides the symposium contributers, this social was attended by 120 people including 85 undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs.  This event gave students a chance to meet the presenters.

    As a result of this symposium, fourteen articles were published in a special issue of Integrative and Comparative Biology that including the symposium presenters plus twenty additional authors including seventeen graduate students.

    In these ways we succeeded in our goal to generate new thinking among both junior and senior scientists about how the interaction of mitochondrial and nuclear genes might shape the rules of life.
